Rappé Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition János Szanyi Writing – review & editing Supervision Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA 99354, USA Pacific Northwest National Laboratory Richland WA 99354 USA Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA 99354, USA ⁎ Corresponding author. The selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NOx with NH3 as the reductant over small-pore Cu-zeolite catalysts is a leading strategy for controlling emissions from diesel engines and mobile sources. While the hydrothermal stability of Cu-zeolites such as Cu-SSZ-13, Cu-SAPO-34, and Cu-SSZ-39 has been extensively studied, the multifaceted role of water vapor under operating conditions has only recently received systematic attention. Water impacts multiple aspects of SCR catalysis, including NOx conversion, N2O formation, Cu ion speciation, redox kinetics, and surface reactions. This review comprehensively summarizes recent advances in understanding the effect of water on NH3-SCR over Cu-based catalysts. For Cu-SSZ-13, water vapor induces both inhibitory and promotive effects depending on temperature, Cu loading, and Si/Al ratio by altering NH3 adsorption, Cu mobility, and redox half-cycle kinetics. Studies have revealed that water can suppress ammonium nitrate formation at low temperatures and enhance nitrate pathways at higher temperatures. Over Cu-SAPO-34, water promotes NO conversion by improving Cu(II) reducibility and strengthening Brønsted acidity. First-principles calculations confirm that water-coordinated Cu species lower O2 activation barriers. In Cu-SSZ-39, water was found to facilitate Cu reduction, migration, and O2 activation, resulting in superior water tolerance and unexpected catalytic promotion. Both experimental and computational studies highlight that water vapor exerts complex, catalyst-dependent effects on NH3-SCR performance, underscoring the need for tailored catalyst designs that leverage beneficial water interactions while minimizing inhibitory impacts. Graphical Abstract Keywords Ammonia selective catalytic reduction Cu-based zeolites Water vapor effects Redox kinetics Cu speciation Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxides (NOx) are major by-products emitted from both mobile (e.g., automobile, locomotive) and stationary (e.g. industrial boiler) combustion sources [1]. The selective catalytic reduction of NOx with ammonia (NH3-SCR) over small-pore Cu-zeolites, such as Cu-SSZ-13, Cu-SAPO-34, and Cu-SSZ-39, can reduce undesirable emissions, particularly in mobile applications with lean burn internal combustion engines (ICEs) [2–5]. Among Cu ion-exchanged zeolites, chabazites (Cu-CHA), have been successfully commercialized for diesel engine aftertreatment systems, owing to their excellent catalytic efficiency, high selectivity to N2, and superior hydrothermal stability [2,6–9]. Fig. 1a displays a representative Cu-CHA structure with possible cation positions. Isolated Cu(II) species are commonly found in two distinct configurations in Cu-CHA: (1) Z2Cu, located in position II, where Cu(II) is coordinated with two adjacent Al sites in the six-membered ring (6MR) and (2) Z1CuOH, in position IV, where Cu(II) is charge-balanced by single Al site in the eight-membered ring (8MR) [10]. Fig. 1b shows a typical steady-state NH3-SCR NOx conversion profile over Cu-SSZ-13 as a function of temperature under lean exhaust conditions, illustrating the high efficiency of Cu-CHA under realistic operating conditions. Over the past decade, extensive research has elucidated the fundamental aspects of NH3-SCR over Cu-CHA catalysts, including the characterization of active Cu sites [12–16], titration of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites [17,18], elucidation of detailed reaction mechanisms [19–21], and investigations into hydrothermal aging behavior [11,22,23]. Mechanistically, the NH3-SCR (4 NH3 + 4 NO + O2 → 4 N2 + 6 H2O) proceeds via coupled redox half-cycles: a reduction half-cycle (RHC), in which isolated Cu(II) species are reduced to Cu(I) by reaction with NO and NH3, and an oxidation half-cycle (OHC), where Cu(I) is subsequently reoxidized to Cu(II) by O2 [14,19,20,24–26]. The H2O molecules present in engine exhaust play a complex role in the activity and stability of SCR catalysts. Over the past decade, extensive research conducted on the hydrothermal stability of Cu-CHA, especially Cu-SSZ-13 due to its deployment in diesel engine exhaust aftertreatment systems [11], has provided a detailed understanding of the catalyst aging mechanism. As discussed above, two dominant Cu species have been identified in Cu-SSZ-13: Z2Cu, located in the 6MR and Z1CuOH, located in the 8MR. The Z2Cu species exhibits greater thermal stability. Under hydrothermal aging (HTA) conditions, Z1CuOH species gradually convert to Z2Cu species or agglomerate into inactive CuO clusters [27]. The formation of CuO not only reduces SCR activity but also promotes mesopore formation through migration and condensation processes, consequently leading to zeolite structural degradation [27]. These effects are exacerbated by high Cu loadings, elevated Si/Al ratios, and high aging temperature [27–29]. In addition to Cu species transformation under HTA conditions, dealumination of the CHA framework has also been identified as a critical degradation pathway, especially at higher aging temperature (≥ 750 °C), decreasing Brønsted acid sites [30]. While these insights have been critical for guiding catalyst formulation and long-term durability, the effects of hydrothermal aging are not the focus of this review. Rather, this review will focus on the current understanding of how water vapor influences SCR reaction pathways and redox kinetics over Cu-CHA catalysts. Although significant progress has been made in fundamental understanding of NH3-SCR mechanism over Cu-CHA catalysts, detailed investigations into the influence of water vapor, a ubiquitous component of real-world combustion exhaust streams, have only recently begun. To date, studies have demonstrated that water impacts multiple SCR performance in multiple ways, including competitive adsorption [31,32], Cu ion speciation and mobility [31], redox kinetics [16,33,34], and reaction intermediate formation such as ammonium nitrate (NH4NO3) [32]. Understanding these effects is especially important for emerging engine technologies. Hydrogen internal combustion engines (H2-ICEs) have been gaining interest as a potential technology in the transportation sector, especially in heavy-duty applications [35]. Given the growing interest in H2-ICEs, in which exhaust streams can contain significantly higher water vapor concentrations compared to diesel engine exhaust, up to 30 % by volume [36], the need for a detailed understanding of the effect of water on NH3-SCR over Cu-CHA has become increasingly urgent. Developing this fundamental understanding is crucial for guiding catalyst design strategies aimed at achieving robust performance under challenging environments. Considering these emerging challenges, this review summarizes recent advances in understanding the effect of water vapor on NH3-SCR performance over several Cu-based zeolite catalysts, including Cu-SSZ-13, Cu-SAPO-34, and Cu-SSZ-39. Emphasis is placed on water’s influence on NO conversion, N2O formation, Cu speciation, redox cycle kinetics and reaction mechanisms. Differences between catalyst frameworks and compositions are discussed, and key findings from experimental and computational studies are integrated to provide a comprehensive perspective. 2 Effect of H2O on NH3-SCR over small-pore Cu-ion exchanged zeolite catalysts A summary of the key studies investigating the effect of water on NH3-SCR over Cu-loaded zeolite catalysts is provided in Table 1. To provide a comprehensive picture, the table includes catalyst type, Cu loading, Si/Al ratio, H2O concentration, temperature range studied, gas hourly space velocity (GHSV), and the impact of water on SCR activity. This comparative table highlights the fact that the majority of existing studies on water impact have focused on Cu-SSZ-13, whereas investigations on Cu-SAPO-34 and Cu-SSZ-39 remain comparatively limited. This is understandable considering Cu-SSZ-13 has emerged as the primary choice for real-world deployment in diesel engines. However, this distribution underscores the need for further exploration across different small-pore zeolite frameworks, particularly as future emission control strategies target increasingly water-rich exhaust environments, such as in H2-ICE exhaust, where Cu-SSZ-13 may not always be the best choice [37]. 2.1 Effect of H2O on NH3-SCR over Cu-SSZ-13 2.1.1 Effect of H2O on global NH3-SCR activity Although hydrothermal stability of Cu-zeolites has been extensively studied [11,50], the dynamic effect of water vapor on deNOx performance under typical operating conditions is still not well understood. This section highlights key discoveries regarding the effect of water on NH3-SCR over Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts. One of the earliest systematic investigations into water’s influence was reported by Ruggeri et al. [38], who performed NO oxidation and standard NH3-SCR over commercial Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst under dry feed and in the presence of 8 % H2O. The presence of H2O inhibited NO oxidation to NO2. On the other hand, SCR activity at low temperatures (< 250 °C) was not impacted, while high-temperature (> 300 °C) activity was improved due to a decreased NH3 oxidation in the presence of water. Complementary NH3-SCR was also performed over Cu-SSZ-13 sample wash coated on a monolith at 180 °C, using sequential feeds of 500 ppm NO, NO + 8 % O2, and NO + 8 % O2 + 500 ppm NH3, under dry and wet (10 % H2O) conditions. Under dry conditions, 80 % NO conversion was achieved, while in the presence of 10 % H2O, a lower NO conversion of 70 % was achieved, indicating the SCR activity is negatively impacted with higher H2O content under certain operating conditions. Both inhibitory and promotive effect of H2O on NH3-SCR activities have been reported in several studies. The influence of Cu loading (1.3, 2.8, and 6.5 wt%) on NH3-SCR activity under dry and wet (5 % H2O) conditions has been studied, showing that water can inhibit or enhance NO conversion depending on temperature and Cu content [41]. For 1.3 % Cu-SSZ-13, NO conversion was slightly inhibited below 200 °C and above 420 °C, while slightly enhanced between 200 – 420 °C in the presence of H2O. For 2.8 % Cu-SSZ-13, three temperature regions were identified with the presence of H2O: (i) at 160 – 280 °C, NO conversion was negatively impacted, (ii) at 280 – 500 °C, H2O had little effect, and (iii) above 520 °C, NO conversion was enhanced. In the case of 6.5 % Cu-SSZ-13, NO conversion was inhibited below 480 °C but enhanced above 500 °C in the presence of H2O. The low-temperature inhibition was attributed to competitive adsorption of H2O on the active sites. The catalytic activity of commercial Cu-SSZ-13 monoliths has been examined under both dry and wet (5 % H2O) conditions, revealing temperature-dependent inhibitory or promotive effect of H2O on NH3-SCR activity [32]. As shown in Fig. 2a, the SCR activity was inhibited at low temperatures (< 250 °C) but enhanced at high temperatures (> 300 °C) in the presence of water. To understand the origin of these effects, a series of temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) experiments, including NH3-TPD and NOx-TPD were performed. TPD was conducted following NH3 adsorption at 100 °C and 200 °C, both in the presence and absence of H2O. As shown in Fig. 2b-e, the presence of 5 % H2O significantly decreases the amount of physisorbed NH3, and NH3 bound to Lewis and Brønsted acid sites by 63 %, 73 %, and 34 %, respectively, when NH3 was adsorbed at 100 °C. Similarly, after adsorption at 200 °C and subsequent TPD analysis, NH3 bound to Lewis acid sites and Brønsted acid sites decreased by 42 % and 92 %, respectively. These reductions in the amount of adsorbed NH3 was attributed to hydrolysis of Z2Cu species to Z1CuOH and to the formation of [Cu(H2O)6]2+ complexes, which inhibit NH3 adsorption over Lewis acid sites, ultimately leading to the inhibitory effect of H2O on low-temperature SCR activity. NO2- and NO-TPD measurements revealed that NO2 desorption amount increased by 70 % and 15 %, respectively, in the presence of H2O, suggesting the promotion of nitrate formation. To further elucidate the impact of H2O on the reaction mechanism, in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) experiments were performed under dry (NH3 + NO + O2/N2) and wet (NH3 + NO + O2 + H2O/N2) conditions across a temperature range of 25 – 350 °C ( Fig. 3) [32]. Under dry conditions, IR bands associated with Brønsted acid site-bound NH4 + ions gradually shifted from 1459 to 1422 cm−1, suggesting the formation of NH4NO3. On the other hand, this shift in peak position was not observed under wet conditions, indicating that H2O inhibits NH4NO3 formation. Transient DRIFTS experiments were also performed to clarify H2O effects at different temperatures (200 and 350 °C). After NH3 saturation and N2 purging, NO + O2/N2 or NO + O2 + H2O/N2 was introduced, and the consumption of Brønsted acid-bound NH4 + (B-NH4 +) and Lewis acid-bound NH3 (L-NH3) species was monitored over time. As shown in Fig. 4, at 200 °C, consumption of B-NH4 + and L-NH3 was hindered by the presence of H2O, while at 350 °C, consumption was significantly accelerated. From these results, it is suggested that at low temperatures, competitive adsorption of H2O and inhibited NH4NO3 formation contribute to the decreased SCR activity, while at high temperatures, water facilitates surface nitrate formation and, consequently gaseous NO2 release, which can directly react with Brønsted-bound NH4 + to enhance the SCR activity. 2.1.2 Effect of H2O on Cu speciation and byproduct formation The influence of H2O on Cu speciation and NH3 adsorption has been examined using NH3-TPD [31]. NH3-TPD experiments were performed under both dry and wet (5 % H2O) conditions with Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts with varying Cu loadings and SiO2/Al2O3 ratios (SAR). The presence of H2O significantly decreased NH3 adsorption on Lewis acid sites, while slightly increasing NH3 storage on Brønsted acid sites across all tested catalysts. The decrease in low-temperature NH3 desorption signals ( Fig. 5) under wet conditions indicates that H2O preferentially occupied Cu sites, effectively outcompeting NH3. Additionally, H2O found to induce partial hydrolysis of Z2Cu species into Z1CuOH and Brønsted acid sites, resulting in a shift in the NH3/Cu adsorption ratios. Under dry conditions, NH3/Cu ratios ranged from 3 – 4 with gas-phase NH3 and 1 – 2 without it, while under wet conditions, these values converged toward ∼3 or ∼1, respectively. The extent of Z2Cu hydrolysis varied depending on catalyst composition, reaching up to ∼70 % conversion of Z2Cu species in 1.7Cu-SAR25 (1.7 % Cu, SAR = 25) sample. Although NH3-TPD experiments under wet conditions provided valuable information about water-induced Cu species transformation, TPD alone is not sufficient for accurate Cu speciation due to complications like Cu reduction during temperature program under inert N2 flow and water-NH3 competitive adsorption. The use of complementary techniques, such as NO2-TPD and H2-TPR is recommended for more reliable quantification of Cu sites. The sensitivity of Cu speciation to local environment has been highlighted by Borfecchia et al., who used X-ray absorption and emission spectroscopy to demonstrate that thermal dehydration of Cu(II) ions in Cu-SSZ-13 changes coordination geometry and redox properties [51]. Although the abovementioned work focused on dry-state dehydration, it highlights that Cu ion behavior is highly responsive to temperature, hydration, and ligand coordination. Building on these findings, more recent investigation has revealed how water-induced hydrolysis of Z2Cu to Z1CuOH plays a role in Cu speciation and catalytic behavior in NH3-SCR over Cu-SSZ-13 with direct spectroscopic, kinetic and computational evidence [42]. Transient CO oxidation experiments, transient RHC kinetics, in situ FTIR spectroscopy, and density functional theory (DFT) with ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) calculations demonstrated that the hydrolysis of Z2Cu to Z1CuOH is both thermodynamically and kinetically favorable in the presence of H2O and NH3. As shown in Fig. 6a and b, only mobile Z1CuOH, not Z2Cu, can form the dinuclear Cu(II) pairs essential for SCR activity, with H2O promoting the extent of CO oxidation by facilitating Z2Cu hydrolysis. Computational results further revealed that although the hydrolysis is slightly endergonic, the subsequent formation of Cu(II) pairs makes the overall process highly favorable, with an activation barrier of 66 kJ/mol, comparable to that of the NH3-SCR redox. Importantly, hydrolysis does not take place in the absence of NH3 as confirmed by CO oxidation tests in the absence of NH3 under dry and wet conditions (Fig. 6c), highlighting the essential role of NH3. These findings highlight the indispensable role of H2O and NH3 in the dynamic interconversion of Cu species under NH3-SCR conditions. Furthermore, steady-state NH3-SCR kinetics combined with operando electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectroscopy have demonstrated that water-induced hydrolysis of Z2Cu to Z1CuOH plays a crucial role in enhancing Cu mobility and redox activity, which are essential for low-temperature NH3-SCR over Cu-SSZ-13 [43]. Increasing Cu loading was found to promote hydrolysis, leading to a higher fraction of mobile Z1CuOH species that facilitate intercage Cu transfer, the formation of Cu(II) pairs, and consequently improved NH3-SCR performance. Operando EPR measurements at low temperature ( Fig. 7) revealed that mobile Cu species display distinct hyperfine and superhyperfine patterns linked to their coordination environments. For example, at 100 °C, low Cu-loaded samples (Cu-1: 0.16 wt% and Cu-2: 0.35 wt%) exhibited nine superhyperfine lines, indicating the presence of Cu(II)(NH3)4. As Cu loading increased (Cu-3: 0.64 wt% to Cu-5: 1.28 wt%), the superhyperfine signals became less resolved, showing seven-line patterns attributed to partially solvated Cu(II)(OL)(NH3)3 or Cu(II)(OH)(NH3)3 species. At the highest Cu loading (Cu-6: 2.43 wt% and Cu-7: 2.75 wt%), superhyperfine features disappeared, likely due to strong spin-spin broadening associated with increased Cu-ion mobility. These findings highlight the critical role of hydrolysis in controlling Cu mobility, speciation, and catalytic turnover under SCR conditions. In addition to its effect on Cu speciation and NH3 adsorption, water vapor also influences byproduct formation, particularly N2O. The formation characteristics of N2O in both standard SCR and fast SCR reactions over Cu-SSZ-13 have been investigated in the presence and absence of 5 % H2O [40]. Under standard SCR conditions, the presence of water minimally impacted N2O formation below 300 °C but substantially reduced N2O formation at higher temperatures compared to dry conditions. Under fast SCR conditions, the role of H2O became more pronounced, with water reducing N2O emissions across the entire temperature range. Ammonium nitrate (NH4NO3)-TPD experiments ( Fig. 8) revealed that, under dry conditions, Cu-SSZ-13 accumulated more NH4NO3, which decomposed predominantly into N2O at lower temperatures. In contrast, water vapor suppressed the accumulation of NH4NO3 by destabilizing nitrate intermediates, attributed to the cleavage of Cu–O–Cu dimers into more labile Cu–OH species. Furthermore, water altered the decomposition pathway of residual NH4NO3, favoring the formation of NO2 and N2 rather than N2O. 2.1.3 Redox kinetics and reaction mechanisms In addition to impacting global SCR activity, Cu speciation, and by-product formation, water has also been shown to influence redox kinetics of Cu active sites during the NH3-SCR reaction. Using transient kinetic methods, Gramigni et al. [39] systematically investigated the effect of water on the reduction half-cycle (RHC) of standard NH3-SCR over Cu-SSZ-13. The authors found that the presence of 2 % H2O significantly inhibited the reduction rate of Cu(II) sites by NO + NH3; this was evident from a lower apparent 2nd-order rate constant (kRHC) and a reduced apparent activation energy (Ea) compared to dry conditions ( Fig. 9). Specifically, the apparent Ea dropped from ∼55 kJ/mol under dry conditions to ∼30 kJ/mol under wet conditions for the 1.7 % Cu-SSZ-13 with SAR = 25 sample, as shown in the Arrhenius plots (Fig. 9a), indicating that water fundamentally altered the energetics of the reduction step. Despite the inhibition, the 2nd-order dependence of the reduction rate on the fraction of oxidized Cu sites was preserved under wet conditions, supporting the belief that dinuclear Cu(II) species mediated the RHC even in the presence of water. Importantly, while water slowed the reduction kinetics, it did not affect the extent of Cu(II) reduction, nor did it affect the fundamental mechanistic pathway involving Cu-pair structures. These results offer valuable insights into how H2O weakens the Cu(II) reducibility, potentially via competitive adsorption or structural changes in the ammonia-solvated Cu complexes, without destroying the dinuclear Cu(II) species necessary for the RHC. Building on prior kinetic analyses, Nasello et al. [33] systematically investigated the impact of water vapor on the RHC of NH3-SCR over Cu-SSZ-13 using transient response methods at 135 – 350 °C. Below 200 °C, 2 – 5 % H2O slowed the reduction rate of Cu(II) sites by NO + NH3, versus dry conditions as shown in Fig. 10a, while maintaining the overall reducibility of Cu sites (∼12 μmol). Kinetic fitting indicated that the reaction remained 2nd-order in Cu(II) and 1st-order in NO, consistent with dry conditions. Arrhenius plots (Fig. 10b) revealed that the presence of H2O decreased the apparent Ea from ∼50 kJ/mol (dry) to ∼36 – 38 kJ/mol (wet), similar to the values reported by Gramigni et al. [39] At higher temperatures (220 – 350 °C), water continued to inhibit Cu(II) reduction, with slower apparent rates and a higher temperature onset for diffusional limitations compared to dry conditions. The authors attributed the inhibitory effect of water to stabilization of the transition state during Cu(II) reduction, causing a kinetic penalty. Interestingly, these effects were largely independent of H2O concentration between 2 % and 5 %. These results reinforce that water inhibits Cu redox kinetics in NH3-SCR, both at low and high temperatures, without fundamentally altering the mechanistic nature of the RHC. Consistent with experimental observations, theoretical investigations have provided complementary mechanistic insights into the pathway of water influence on the Cu redox cycle during NH3-SCR. Contaldo et al. [52]. performed a DFT study to elucidate the mechanistic role of water during the RHC of low-temperature NH3-SCR over Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts. The calculations indicated that H2O enthalpically stabilizes the kinetically relevant transition state (TS) for NO activation to HONO by ∼20 kJ/mol versus dry conditions ( Fig. 11a). However, this enthalpic stabilization was offset by greater entropy losses due to confinement effects within the CHA cage in the presence of H2O, resulting in larger apparent activation entropy penalties (∼-200 J/mol/K in wet vs. ∼-150 J/mol/K in dry, Fig. 11b). Consequently, although the apparent activation enthalpy decreased from 62 kJ/mol (dry) to 42 kJ/mol (wet), the overall Gibbs free energy barrier was slightly higher under wet conditions (127 kJ/mol wet vs. 125 kJ/mol dry, Fig. 11c), leading to a net inhibition of the RHC rate. These theoretical results showed good agreement with experimental kinetic data reported by Gramigni et al. [39] and Nasello et al. [33], further validating that water affects NH3-SCR performance by modulating the free energy landscape of the Cu redox cycle through enthalpy-entropy trade-offs. Operando UV/Vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS) combined with transient kinetic analysis has been applied to quantitatively investigate the RHC of NH3-SCR over Cu-SSZ-13 (1.77 wt% Cu, SAR = 25) under both dry and wet (2 % H2O) conditions at 175 °C [44]. The UV/Vis spectra exhibited two characteristic Cu(II) features: (1) a broad d–d transition near 15,100 cm−1 and (2) ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) bands at ∼26,000 cm−1 ( Fig. 12a). During the RHC transient, the intensity of these features progressively diminished, indicating the reduction of Cu(II) to Cu(I). Multivariate Curve Resolution (MCR) analysis quantified the fraction of oxidized Cu(II) and showed that the reduction was nearly complete after 500 s (Fig. 12c). Furthermore, kinetic modeling confirmed a first-order dependence on NO and a second-order dependence on oxidized Cu(II). The apparent rate constants were 10.5 × 10−3s−1 under dry condition and 7.5 × 10−3 s−1 under wet condition, demonstrating that water inhibits the RHC by decreasing the reduction rate constant. These results support a dual-Cu-site mechanism for the RHC in NH3-SCR over Cu-SSZ-13 and highlight operando UV/Vis with MCR can be a powerful approach for extracting quantitative kinetic and mechanistic information. Recent studies have also revealed that water can promote the oxidation half-cycle (OHC) of the NH3-SCR reaction. Nasello et al. [34] investigated the effect of H2O on low-temperature NH3-SCR over Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts with different SiO2/Al2O3 ratios (SAR = 10, 17, 25) using transient kinetic analysis. Over Cu-SSZ-13 with SAR = 25, the presence of 2 % H2O promoted the OHC rate while inhibiting the RHC rate at 150 – 200 °C, as observed by faster Cu(I) reoxidation profiles under wet conditions and decreased NO consumption rates. Despite these opposite effects, steady-state NO conversion during standard SCR remained largely unaffected by H2O, while the Cu(II) fraction increased. When examining catalysts with lower SARs, the effect of H2O on RHC shifted from inhibition (SAR = 25) to negligible (SAR = 17) to promotion (SAR = 10), while the promoting effect on OHC was consistently observed across all samples ( Fig. 13). As a result, for Cu-SSZ-13 with SAR = 10, water enhanced both half-cycle rates, leading to a noticeable improvement in steady-state NO conversion under wet conditions. Activation energy analysis revealed that wet conditions decreased the apparent RHC activation energy while increasing the OHC activation energy, consistent with an H2O-assisted stabilization of transition states. The authors attributed the SAR-dependent behavior to the influence of aluminum density on the enthalpic stabilization during the RHC transition state in the presence of H2O. This study demonstrated that the interplay between SAR and water governs the redox kinetics in Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts and thus impacts NH3-SCR performance. Complementary spectroscopic evidence has further corroborated the promotional effect of water on the OHC. In-situ DRIFTS and XANES studies revealed that the addition of 5 % H2O enhanced NOx conversion at low temperature (150 – 300 °C) and increased the pre-exponential factor despite raising the apparent Ea from 38.9 to 52.5 kJ/mol [16]. DRIFT spectra showed that water weakened the interaction between Cu ions and the zeolite framework compared to dry conditions, consistent with the hypothesis that H2O promotes solvation of [Cu(NH3)2]+ species and enhances Cu mobility within the CHA cage. Time-resolved DRIFTS monitoring of the 893 cm−1 peak (zeolite T–O–T framework by the interaction with ion exchanged Cu(II)) indicated that the extent of Cu ion reduction decreased in the presence of H2O, suggesting faster re-oxidation of Cu(I) under wet conditions. In-situ XANES measurements confirmed that the fraction of Cu(I) formed upon NO exposure was lower under wet conditions ( Fig. 14c), and the oxidation of [Cu(I)(NH3)2]+ intermediates was accelerated (Fig. 14d). The results indicate that water promotes the OHC by enhancing the proximity and reactivity of Cu ions, thus facilitating the formation of dimeric Cu intermediates and improving NH3-SCR activity at low temperature. In addition to facilitating the OHC by H2O-assisted transition state stabilization and enhancement of Cu mobility, water vapor may also directly participate in the OHC through a distinct mechanistic pathway. A previously unreported H2O-only OHC pathway in Cu-SSZ-13 has been identified, in which Cu(I) species were progressively reoxidized to Cu(II) upon exposure to H2O alone, without the presence of O2 or NO, at 300 °C [53]. This observation contradicts the prior understanding that both O2 and NO are needed for Cu reoxidation during the redox cycle. However, similar observation of H2O-induced Cu(I) oxidation has been reported during methanol formation from methane on Cu-zeolites [54–56]. The proposed mechanism may involve the reverse of an auto-reduction pathway where Cu(II) is known to reduce to Cu(I) by releasing OH-, introducing an additional pathway that could affect SCR performance under wet conditions. The authors noted that detailed theoretical mechanistic investigation would be required to understand reoxidation of Cu(I) with only H2O. While most studies have focused on the role of water at concentrations typical of diesel exhaust (up to ∼10 %), emerging ICE applications (i.e., H2-ICEs) necessitate NH3-SCR investigations under more extreme environments. Deka et al. [37] investigated the influence of high H2O and H2 levels typical of H2-ICE exhaust conditions on the NH₃-SCR activity and stability of Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts. Under steady-state conditions, 3 % H2O improved NOx conversion at low temperatures (< 280 °C) compared to dry conditions, primarily by enhancing Cu ion mobility and hydrolysis ( Fig. 15a). This finding agrees well with the observations by Lee et al. [16], where 5 % H2O enhanced NOx conversions at low temperatures and Nasello et al. [34], where 2 % H2O promoted the OHC rate. However, increasing H2O content above 3 % progressively inhibited NOx conversion, with 20 % H2O reducing low-temperature SCR efficiency by nearly 20 % compared to 3 % H₂O. Arrhenius analysis revealed that both Ea and pre-exponential factor increased from dry to 3–10 % H2O due to enhanced O2 activation, but both decreased at 20 % H2O. This suggests that excessive water shifts the reaction back to being OHC-limited (Fig. 15b and c). High H2O content also increased N2O byproduct formation, likely from hindered Cu(NH3)2 diffusion (Fig. 15d). The authors pointed out that under realistic H2O content (20 %) in H2-ICE exhaust condition, Cu-SSZ-13 performance is compromised, indicating the need for more resilient catalyst designs that can withstand the negative effect of elevated water vapor levels. The impact of water partial pressure on NH3-SCR over Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts has been systematically investigated across a wide range of H2O concentrations (0 – 25 %) using a combination of steady-state NH3-SCR experiments and DFT-based microkinetic modeling [45]. NOx conversion at 200 °C over Cu-SSZ-13 (3.2 wt%, SiAl = 6.7) initially increased when comparing dry and 2 % H2O conditions, but progressively decreased as the H2O concentration further raised from 2 % to 25 % ( Fig. 16a). The apparent reaction order in H2O decreased from −0.17 to −1.18 as the partial pressure of H2O increased from 2 % to 25 %, which reflects increased inhibition of water at high partial pressures (Fig. 16b). Kinetic analysis revealed that the SCR reaction maintained first-order dependence on NO and near-zero-order dependence on NH3, while the effective rate constant steadily decreased with increasing H2O levels. DFT calculations showed that water adsorbs onto key Cu(II) intermediates, specifically [Cu2(NH3)4O2]2+ and [Cu2(NH3)4(OH)2]2+ with adsorption energies of 0.79 eV and 0.59 eV, respectively. Since the adsorption energies of NO on [Cu2(NH3)4O2]2+ and [Cu2(NH3)4(OH)2]2+ are 0.70 eV and 0.39 eV, respectively, H2O is considered to directly compete with NO adsorption and thereby inhibiting the redox cycle. A mean-field microkinetic model incorporating H2O adsorption steps accurately reproduced the experimental inhibition trends after adjusting the entropy of water adsorption and introducing a weak partial-pressure-dependent Gibbs free energy correction. The model confirmed that at high H2O pressures, Cu-complexes blocked by water, specifically [H2OCu2(NH3)4OHOH]2+ and [H2OCu2(NH3)4O2]2+, are prevalent at the catalyst surface, effectively suppressing NH3-SCR activity. The study proposed a simple Langmuir-type expression can describe the observed water-dependent rate decline, highlighting competitive adsorption of H2O on active Cu(II) sites as the primary mechanism of inhibition. 2.2 Effect of H2O on NH3-SCR over Cu-SAPO-34 and Cu-SSZ-39 Cu-SAPO-34 and Cu-SSZ-13 are two widely studied small-pore zeolite catalysts for NH3-SCR, providing comparable NH3-SCR activity and hydrothermal stability [57–59]. This section presents recent studies on the effect of water vapor on NH3-SCR over Cu-SAPO-34 and Cu-SSZ-39 catalysts. Yu et al. [46] studied the effects of water vapor and CO2 on NH3-SCR performance over Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts with different acidities (Cu-1 with 0.176 µmol/m2 acid density and Cu-2 with 0.328 µmol/m2 acid density). NH3-SCR tests showed that CO₂ addition had negligible influence, while 3 % H2O addition improved NO conversion across the entire temperature range and decreased N2O and NO2 side-product formation. NH3-TPD results revealed that H2O increased the strength of Brønsted acid sites, indicated by a shift of desorption peaks to higher temperatures, and promoted the reducibility of Cu(II) species. Kinetic analysis at low temperature (150 – 225 °C) showed that H2O decreased the apparent Ea for NH3-SCR from ∼43 to ∼19 kJ/mol for both Cu-1 and Cu-2 samples ( Fig. 17a and b), enhancing NO conversion rates. The authors attributed this improvement to the increased reducibility of Cu(II) species and enhanced acidity through hydrogen bonding between adsorbed NH3 and H2O molecules. Gas switching and transient NH3-TPD experiments confirmed that H2O increased the adsorbed NH3 amount and acid site strength. At high temperatures (410 – 490 °C), H2O suppressed NH3 oxidation, raising the Ea of NH3 oxidation from ∼54 – 52 kJ/mol (dry) to ∼69 – 74 kJ/mol (wet) (Fig. 17c and d), thus reducing undesired side-products and enhancing NOx conversion during SCR. Overall, the study demonstrated that H2O positively impacts Cu-SAPO-34 SCR performance by improving Cu reducibility, strengthening acidity, and suppressing NH3 oxidation. Cortés-Reyes et al. [47] studied the impact of H2O and CO2 co-fed on NH3-SCR over a 2 % Cu-SAPO-34 catalyst that was synthesized via one-pot method with all copper inside the framework. Under standard SCR conditions, the presence of 1.5 % H2O + 0.3 % CO2 improved NOx conversion at low temperatures (< 250 °C) and enhanced N2 selectivity, while suppressing side reactions such as ammonia oxidation and nitrate decomposition. As shown in Fig. 18 and Fig. 19, NH3-SCR NO conversion increased, while NH3 oxidation conversion decreased in the presence of H2O. These trends agree well with the observations reported by Yu et al. [46], where the presence of H2O promoted the SCR activity while suppressing the NH3 oxidation. NH3-TPD experiments showed that H2O + CO2 atmosphere decreased ammonia storage capacity compared to dry conditions, attributed to competitive adsorption and carbonation over the active sites. Thermogravimetric-mass spectrometry (TG-MS) and FTIR analyses confirmed that CO2 adsorption occurred only after surface hydration, leading to formation of multiple carbonate species stabilized by hydrated Cu centers. In the SCR temperature range, hydrated-carbonated Cu(I) and Cu(II) species were proposed as the active intermediates, maintaining high NOx conversion (∼80 %) and high N2 selectivity without N2O formation. The promoting effects of H2O on NH3-SCR performance over Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts with varying Cu loadings (1.16, 1.56, and 2.51 %) have been investigated [48]. The addition of 5 % H2O was found to improved NOx conversion across the entire temperature range studied (200 – 500 °C), with more pronounced enhancement observed at lower Cu loadings under both 5 % and 10 % O2 conditions. As shown in Fig. 20, transient experiments at 200 °C demonstrated that water addition induces both a temporary enhancement (denoted as A and B), due to accelerated Cu(I) reoxidation to Cu(II), and a permanent improvement through water-assisted migration and stabilization of Cu ions at framework sites (denoted as C). The temporary enhancement is reversible, while the permanent enhancement is irreversible once the effect takes place under the initial H2O exposure. Furthermore, H2-TPR measurements showed that water shifted Cu reduction peaks to higher temperatures, indicating better Cu dispersion. Complementary NH3-TPD and XPS analyses revealed an increase in Brønsted acidity and a reduction in surface CuO content following water exposure, consistent with enhanced Cu redistribution. DFT calculations further supported these findings and, suggested that water stabilizes key redox transition states without promoting hydrolysis of active Cu species ([Cu–O–Cu]2+ and Z2Cu-6MR) under typical SCR conditions. Overall, water was shown to promote NH3-SCR over Cu-SAPO-34 by enhancing Cu reoxidation kinetics, increasing Brønsted acidity, stabilizing active Cu sites, and suppressing undesired NH3 oxidation at high temperatures. To complement the experimental observations, first-principles calculations have been used to investigate how water influences O2 activation during NH3-SCR over Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts [60]. A thermodynamic phase diagram analysis showed that NH3 preferentially adsorbed onto Cu sites over H2O under dry conditions. However, under low-temperature and high-water partial pressure (∼0.1 atm), co-adsorption of H2O and NH3 becomes thermodynamically favorable, leading to Cu(NH3)(H2O)+ species formation. O2 activation over Cu(NH3)2 +–Cu(NH3)2 + pairs exhibited a high activation barrier (0.73 eV), but the introduction of a Cu(NH3)(H2O)⁺ unit reduced the O2 activation barrier to 0.41 eV ( Fig. 21). This reduction was attributed to a distortion in the Cu–O–O–Cu torsion angle from 106° to 127°, which weakened the O–O bond and facilitated O2 dissociation (Fig. 21b). These results provide a molecular-level explanation for the experimentally observed promotional effect of water on low-temperature SCR activity by stabilizing co-adsorbed intermediates and lowering kinetic barriers for O2 activation. Finally, Fu et al. [49] investigated the effect of water vapor on NH3-SCR performance over Cu-SSZ-39 catalysts by combining experimental measurements and DFT calculations. The addition of 0.5 – 5 % H2O promoted or maintained high NOx conversion over Cu-SSZ-39, with activity only decreasing at 8 % H2O. DFT calculations indicated that H2O coordination with Cu sites facilitates two critical steps: lowering the energy barrier for Cu(II) reduction (from 1.00 eV for Cu(II)(NH3)4 to 0.86 eV for Cu(II)(H2O)(NH3)3, Fig. 22) and enhancing intercage diffusion of Cu(I) species by decreasing the migration barrier (from 0.62 eV to 0.41 eV). Water also reduced the energy barrier for O2 activation over Cu(I) pairs from 0.77 eV (without H2O) to 0.51 eV (with H2O), resulting in a shift of the rate-determining step from O2 activation to NO activation. In-situ DRIFTS experiments confirmed that H2O preferentially coordinated with Lewis acid Cu sites and promoted NO activation and SCR turnover. The study concludes that H2O acts not only as a ligand but also as a reactant, stabilizing transition states and reducing kinetic barriers throughout the SCR cycle, explaining the superior water tolerance and unexpected promotional effect observed for Cu-SSZ-39. 3 Conclusions and outlook We have shown that the effect of water on NH3-SCR performance over Cu-based zeolite catalysts is complex and highly catalyst-dependent. For Cu-SSZ-13, water has been shown to inhibit NO oxidation but exerts minimal or even promotional effects on standard SCR activity depending on temperature. Water competes with NH3 for adsorption on Lewis acid Cu ions, induces partial hydrolysis of Z2Cu species to Z1CuOH and Brønsted acid sites, and influences the formation and decomposition of ammonium nitrate intermediates. At low temperatures, competitive adsorption and suppressed NH4NO3 formation inhibit SCR activity, whereas at high temperatures, enhanced surface nitrate formation and improved Cu mobility promote NO conversion. In contrast, Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts generally exhibit positive responses to water addition. Water improves NH3-SCR activity by enhancing the reducibility of Cu(II) species, strengthening Brønsted acidity through hydrogen bonding, and suppressing undesired NH3 oxidation at high temperatures. First-principles studies further support that water-assisted Cu(NH3)(H2O)+ species lower the activation barrier for O2 activation, thereby facilitating the SCR reaction. Recent studies on Cu-SSZ-39 have revealed an unexpected promotional effect of water across a broad temperature window. Water has been shown to facilitate Cu reduction, promotes intercage diffusion of Cu ions, and lowers the activation barrier for O2 activation, collectively enhancing SCR activity. The unique framework structure and Cu environment in SSZ-39 enable a positive interaction with water vapor, distinguishing its behavior from that of conventional Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts. Studies presented in this review demonstrate that the framework topology of small-pore Cu-zeolites may play a crucial role in governing how water influences NH3-SCR performance. Variations in pore connectivity, cage geometry, and acid site distribution can affect Cu speciation, mobility, water adsorption, and redox kinetics. These insights highlight the importance of rational framework selection when designing catalysts operating under water-rich exhaust conditions. Despite these advances, several critical knowledge gaps and development opportunities remain: • Current mechanistic understanding is limited by insufficient time-resolved and operando spectroscopy under H2O-rich environments. Performing in-situ/operando infrared spectroscopy, especially DRIFTS under high H2O content is not desirable because water vapor exhibits strong and broad IR absorption bands near 1600 and 3000 – 3700 cm−1 that overlap with key surface species in NH3-SCR. The presence of H2O also causes unstable baselines and increased noises that subsequently complicates the data interpretation. Additionally, condensation can occur if the optics are cooler than the H2O-containing gas. In contrast, X-ray Absorption Spectroscopy (XAS) can be performed under high H2O concentrations and offers element-specific insights into the oxidation state and local coordination environment of Cu active sites. When coupled with first-principles simulations, XAS can clarify how high-water content influences Cu coordination and redox properties. Advanced operando spectroscopic techniques such as XAS, combined with transient kinetic modeling and first-principles simulations, are expected to provide deeper mechanistic understanding. Similarly, operando electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) under realistic H2O conditions could also provide important insights into Cu-redox behavior. • Although water is known to promote Cu mobility, long-term consequences such as agglomeration, dealumination, or CuOx formation remain incompletely understood, especially under high H2O content. Systematic studies varying Si/Al ratios and Cu loading can reveal composition-dependent stability under high-water exposure. • The formation of redox-active Cu pairs is sensitive to framework topology, Cu spacing, and solvation by ligands such as H2O and NH3. Synthesizing Cu-based small-pore zeolites with controlled Al siting could isolate the contributions of Cu proximity and water-induced Cu migration to SCR activity. • SCR catalysts for H2-ICE applications must remain active and stable under prolonged exposure to high H2O concentrations. However, durability studies under such conditions are scarce. Future efforts should develop accelerated aging protocols representative of H2-ICE exhaust and use post-aging techniques, such as EPR, nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR), and XAS, to detect redox-active Cu content, Cu leaching, framework collapse, and irreversible changes in Cu coordination. • Water vapor has been shown to increase N2O byproduct formation. However, the exact mechanistic pathways remain poorly understood. Future work should combine isotopic labeling experiments with first-principles modeling to determine how excess water shifts the reaction toward higher N2O selectivity. Insights from these studies should inform the design of catalysts that suppress N2O formation, such as by optimizing Cu proximity and redox properties or incorporating secondary cations that modulate intermediate stability under wet conditions. • In environments with high H2O concentrations, catalyst design must address key challenges related to activity, durability, and hydrothermal stability. One approach involves optimizing the Si/Al ratio and controlling Al siting to stabilize redox-active Z2Cu species. While higher Si/Al ratios can enhance hydrophobicity and potentially mitigate adverse effect of high H2O content on the SCR activity, they compromise framework stability and NH3 storage capacity. The incorporation of secondary cations, such as cerium, has shown potential to improve hydrothermal resistance by mitigating framework degradation and inhibiting Cu agglomeration. However, systematic studies that explore the combined effects of hydrophobic modification and secondary cation incorporation under high-H2O conditions are still lacking and present opportunities for future investigations. • The integration of artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) offers potential for catalyst design and mechanistic investigations. Data-driven approaches can accelerate the discovery of robust Cu-zeolite catalysts by predicting optimal framework compositions, stable Cu configurations, and favorable Si/Al ratios under high-H2O contents. However, the amount of experimental and computational datasets specific to NH3-SCR over high H2O levels is currently limited. To fully realize the potential of AI/ML, future efforts should focus on curating robust datasets. Additionally, coupling ML with high-throughput DFT simulations can enable rapid screening of reaction pathways and intermediate stabilization. Addressing these knowledge gaps through integrated experimental, computational, and data-driven approaches will be critical to advancing catalyst development for next-generation NH3-SCR systems. A concerted effort to understand and mitigate the effects of high H2O levels will enable the design of durable, selective, and efficient catalysts. coredata.dc:description: The selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NOx with NH3 as the reductant over small-pore Cu-zeolite catalysts is a leading strategy for controlling emissions from diesel engines and mobile sources. While the hydrothermal stability of Cu-zeolites such as Cu-SSZ-13, Cu-SAPO-34, and Cu-SSZ-39 has been extensively studied, the multifaceted role of water vapor under operating conditions has only recently received systematic attention. Water impacts multiple aspects of SCR catalysis, including NOx conversion, N2O formation, Cu ion speciation, redox kinetics, and surface reactions. This review comprehensively summarizes recent advances in understanding the effect of water on NH3-SCR over Cu-based catalysts. For Cu-SSZ-13, water vapor induces both inhibitory and promotive effects depending on temperature, Cu loading, and Si/Al ratio by altering NH3 adsorption, Cu mobility, and redox half-cycle kinetics. Studies have revealed that water can suppress ammonium nitrate formation at low temperatures and enhance nitrate pathways at higher temperatures. Over Cu-SAPO-34, water promotes NO conversion by improving Cu(II) reducibility and strengthening Brønsted acidity. First-principles calculations confirm that water-coordinated Cu species lower O2 activation barriers. In Cu-SSZ-39, water was found to facilitate Cu reduction, migration, and O2 activation, resulting in superior water tolerance and unexpected catalytic promotion. Both experimental and computational studies highlight that water vapor exerts complex, catalyst-dependent effects on NH3-SCR performance, underscoring the need for tailored catalyst designs that leverage beneficial water interactions while minimizing inhibitory impacts.
